info.description: Dweet.io allows users to share data from mobile, tablets, and pcs, and them to other devices and accounts across social media platforms. Dweet.io provides an API to access the different functionality of the Dweet.io service. Users can make REST calls to read and create dweets, lock and unlock things, and perform other calls. The API returns JSON and JSONP.
info.title: dweet.io

tags.description: Create or read dweets in short term cache.
tags.name: dweets

tags.description: Read dweets from long term storage.
tags.name: storage

parameters.description: A comma separated list of Email addresses to send the alert to.
parameters.name: who

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing. It is recommended that you use a GUID as to avoid name collisions.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A condition that returns a string or a true value if a condition is met.
parameters.name: condition

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

get.summary: Create an alert for a thing. A thing must be locked before an alert can be set.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing. It is recommended that you use a GUID as to avoid name collisions.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: The actual content of the string. Can be any valid JSON string.
parameters.name: content

post.summary: Create a dweet for a thing.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing. It is recommended that you use a GUID as to avoid name collisions.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: The actual content of the string. Can be any valid JSON string.
parameters.name: content

post.summary: Create a dweet for a thing.  This method differs from /dweet/for/{thing} only in that successful dweets result in an HTTP 204 response rather than the typical verbose response.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

get.summary: Get the alert attached to a thing.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

get.summary: Read the last 5 cached dweets for a thing.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

get.summary: Read the latest dweet for a thing.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: The calendar date (YYYY-MM-DD) from which you'd like to start your query.  The response will be a maximum of one day.
parameters.name: date

parameters.description: The hour of the day represented in the date parameter in 24-hour (00-23) format.  If this parameter is included, a maximum of 1 hour will be returned starting at this hour.
parameters.name: hour

parameters.description: Current valid parameters for this are 'csv' and 'json'.  If this parameter is left blank, all responses default to hapi-json dweet-speak.
parameters.name: responseType

get.summary: Read all the saved alerts for a thing from long term storage.  You can query a maximum of 1 day per request and a granularly of 1 hour.

parameters.description: A unique name of a thing.
parameters.name: thing

parameters.description: A valid key for a locked thing. If the thing is not locked, this can be ignored.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: The calendar date (YYYY-MM-DD) from which you'd like to start your query.  The response will be a maximum of one day.
parameters.name: date

parameters.description: The hour of the day represented in the date parameter in 24-hour (00-23) format.  If this parameter is included, a maximum of 1 hour will be returned starting at this hour.
parameters.name: hour

parameters.description: Current valid parameters for this are 'csv' and 'json'.  If this parameter is left blank, all responses default to hapi-json dweet-speak.
parameters.name: responseType

get.summary: Read all the saved dweets for a thing from long term storage.  You can query a maximum of 1 day per request and a granularly of 1 hour.

get.description:
Sorry, this function uses HTTP chunked responses and cannot be tested here. Try something like: 
curl --raw https://dweet.io/listen/for/dweets/from/{thing}
